case_name: Guduthur Thimmappa Brothers v. Excess Profits Tax Officer

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 185 of 1966 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 185 of 1966.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 20, 1962 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 109 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 20, 1962 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 109 of 1960.

facts.text: Mysore High Court dismissed writ petition No. 109 of 1960 on March 20, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgement of the Mysore High Court dated March 20, 1962 dismissing writ petition No. 109 of 1960.

facts.text: Notice dated January 16, 1960 issued by the respondent under s. 15 of the Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940 calling upon the appellants to submit a return of standard profits and profits actually made during chargeable accounting period from October 30, 1943 to October 30, 1944 on ground profits under-assessed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants had prayed therein for the grant of writ for quashing a. numberice dated January 16, 1960 issued by the respondent under s. 15 of the Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940  Act XV of 1940 , hereinafter called the Act, calling upon the appellants to submit a return of the standard profits and the profits actually made during the chargeable accounting period from October 30, 1943 to October 30, 1944 on the ground that the profits had been under-assessed.

facts.text: Appellants carried on business constituting themselves into a partnership called Guduthur Thimmappa Brothers in 1934.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants carried on a business companystituting themselves into a partnership called Guduthur Thimmappa Brothers in 1934.

facts.text: Partners were G. Thimmappa, G. Ekambarappa, and G. Padmanabhan, each representing their respective joint families.

anchor.surface_text: On the date of companymencement of the business the part- ners were G. Thimmappa, G. Ekambarappa, and G. Padmanabhan, each of the partners representing their respective joint families.

facts.text: Business of the firm was in Bellary town and partners were residents of Bellary town during the period the firm was carrying on business.

anchor.surface_text: The business of the firm was in Bellary town and the partners of the firm were residents of Bellary town during the period the firm was carrying on business.

facts.text: Firm was dissolved on October 16, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: The, firm was dissolved on October 16, 1944.

facts.text: Thimmappa, one of the partners, died on April 13, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Thimmappa, one of the partners, died on April 13, 1955.

facts.text: For the chargeable accounting period from October 30, 1943 to April 30, 1944, the Excess Profits Tax Officer took steps to assess the escaped profits of the firm.

anchor.surface_text: For the chargeable accounting period from October 30, 1943 to April 30, 1944, the Excess Profits Tax Officer had taken steps to assess the escaped profits of the firm.

facts.text: Excess Profits Tax Officer issued notices to G. Padmanabhan and G. Ekambarappa as partners of the dissolved firm.

anchor.surface_text: He issued the necessary numberices to G. Padmanabhan and G. Ekambarappa as the partners of the dissolved firm.

facts.text: Excess Profits Tax Officer issued notice to G. M. Prabhu and G. Lakshmidevamma as representatives of G. Thimmappa.

anchor.surface_text: He also issued numberice to G. M. Prabhu and G. Lakshmidevamma as the representatives of G. Thimmappa.

facts.text: Appellants' contention before High Court: as from November 1, 1956 the Act deemed repealed so far as Bellary district concerned, respondent not competent to take proceedings under s.15.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the appellants, before the High Court was that as from November 1, 1956 the Act must be deemed to have been repealed so far as Bellary district is companycerned and therefore the respondent was number companypetent to take any proceedings for determining the escaped income under S. 15 of that Act.

facts.text: High Court rejected appellants' contention on ground that though Act repealed by inclusion of Bellary in Mysore State, liability to pay tax on escaped profits continued by virtue of s.6 General Clauses Act.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected the companytention on the ground that, though the Act stood repealed by reason of the inclusion of Bellary district in Mysore State, the liability to pay tax on the escaped profits companytinued by virtue of s. 6 of the General Clauses Act.

facts.text: Present Bellary district was part of old Madras State, a Part A State, till merger with Mysore State on October 1, 1953, a Part B State.

anchor.surface_text: The present Bellary district was a part of the old Madras State which was a Part A State under the Constitution of India till its merger with the Mysore State on October 1, 1953 which was a Part B State.

facts.text: Mysore State continued to be a Part B State till November 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The Mysore State companytinued to be a Part B State till November 1, 1956.

facts.text: Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940 initially extended to territory of former British India.

anchor.surface_text: The Act extended, when first promulgated, to. the territory of former British India.

facts.text: After Constitution, s.1(2) of Act adapted to extend to whole of India except Part B States by Adaptation of Laws Order, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: After the Constitution came into force, s. 1 2  of the Act was adapted so as to extend the operation of the Act to the whole of India except Part B States by the Adaptation of Laws Order, 1950.

facts.text: After States Reorganisation Act, 1956, s.1(2) adapted by President by Adaptation of Laws Order, 1956 dated December 31, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: After the formation of new States in pursuance of the States Reorgani- sation Act, 1956  Act 37 of 1956 , sub-s.  2  of s. 1 of the Act was adapted by the President by Adaptation of Laws  No. Order, 1956 dated December 31, 1956.

facts.text: As adapted, Act extends to whole of India except territories which immediately before 1st November, 1956 were comprised in Part B State.

anchor.surface_text: Section 1 2  of the Act as adapted read as follows It extends to the whole of India except the territories which immediately before the 1st November, 1956 were companyprised in part B state.

facts.text: Result of adaptation: all provisions of Act stood repealed so far as Bellary district concerned with effect from December 31, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The result of the adaptation was that all the provisions of the Act stood repealed so far as the district of Bellary was companycerned with effect from December 31, 1956.

facts.text: Appellants contended it is not repeal but modification of s.1(2), so s.6 General Clauses Act not applicable.

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended on behalf of the appellants that it is number a case of repeal of the Act and so the provisions of s. 6 of the General Clauses Act companyld number be invoked to sustain the validity of the numberices issued by the respondent under S. 15 of the Act.

facts.text: Court held Adaptation of Laws Order, 1956 resulted in Act no longer applicable in Bellary district, i.e., repealed for that area.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion there is numberjustification for the argument put forward on behalf of the appellants. The result of the Adaptation of Laws Order, 1956 so far as the Act was companycerned, was that the provisions of that Act were numberlonger applicable or in-force in Bellary district.

facts.text: s.6 General Clauses Act applies to partial repeal.

anchor.surface_text: To put it differently, the Act was repealed so far as the area of Bellary 8 6 7 district was companycerned. Repeal of an Act means revocation or abrogation of the Act and, in our opinion, s. 6 of the General Clauses Act applies even in the case of a partial repeal or repeal of part of an Act.

facts.text: Liability to tax arose immediately at end of chargeable accounting period, not at assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The liability of the appellants to tax arose immediately at the end of the chargeable accounting period and number merely at the time when it is quantified by assessment proceedings.

facts.text: Notice under s.15 legally valid; appellants liable for escaped profits.

anchor.surface_text: It follows therefore that the numberice issued under s. 15 of the Act was legally valid and the appellants representing the original partners of the firm companytinued to be liable to be proceeded against under that section for the profits which had escaped taxation.

facts.text: In Wallace Brothers case, Judicial Committee held tax liability arises by charging section, no later than close of previous year.

anchor.surface_text: In Wallace Brothers and Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of income-tax 1 , the Judicial Committee expounded in clear terms the scope of a tax liability under the Income-tax Act. It was observed by the Judicial Committee as follows the rate of tax for the year of assessment may be fixed after the close of the previous year and the assessment will necessarily be made after the close of that year. But the liability to tax arises by virtue of the charging section alone, and it arises number later than the close of the previous year, though quantification of the amount payable is postponed.

facts.text: Respondent contended alternatively that on combined operation of s.53 Andhra Pradesh Act 1953 and s.119 State Reorganisation Act 1956, Act remained in operation in Bellary despite Adaptation Order.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Narsaraju companytended in the alternative that on the companybined operation of S. 53 of the Andhra Pradesh Act  Act 30 of 1953  and s 119 of the State Reorganisation Act  Act 37 of 1956  all the provisions of the Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940 remained in operation in Bellary district in spite of the Adaptation of Laws Order, 1956.

facts.text: Court did not express concluded opinion on alternative contention as appeal dismissed on main ground.

anchor.surface_text: There is great force in. the argument advanced by Mr. Narsaraju on this point. But it is number necessary for us to express any companycluded opinion on this aspect of the case because we have -already given reasons for holding that the appeal must be dismissed on the ground that the Act stood repealed by reason of the Adaptation of Laws Order, 1956 and the liability to pay tax on escaped profits companytinued under s. 6 of the General Clauses Act.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion there is no justification for the argument put forward on behalf of the appellants. The result of the Adaptation of Laws Order, 1956 so far as the Act was concerned, was that the provisions of that Act were no longer applicable or in-force in Bellary district.

holdings.text: The result of the Adaptation of Laws Order, 1956 so far as the Act was concerned, was that the provisions of that Act were no longer applicable or in-force in Bellary district.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion there is numberjustification for the argument put forward on behalf of the appellants. The result of the Adaptation of Laws Order, 1956 so far as the Act was companycerned, was that the provisions of that Act were numberlonger applicable or in-force in Bellary district.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adaptation modified s.1(2) making Act inapplicable to Bellary as former Part B territory, equivalent to repeal for that area despite appellants' argument of mere modification.

holdings.text: s. 6 of the General Clauses Act applies even in the case of a partial repeal or repeal of part of an Act.

anchor.surface_text: To put it differently, the Act was repealed so far as the area of Bellary 8 6 7 district was companycerned. Repeal of an Act means revocation or abrogation of the Act and, in our opinion, s. 6 of the General Clauses Act applies even in the case of a partial repeal or repeal of part of an Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Repeal defined as revocation; s.6 textually applies to any Central Act repealing enactment, including partial repeal; 'enactment' under s.3(19) includes provisions.

holdings.text: The liability of the appellants to tax arose immediately at the end of the chargeable accounting period and not merely at the time when it is quantified by assessment proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The liability of the appellants to tax arose immediately at the end of the chargeable accounting period and number merely at the time when it is quantified by assessment proceedings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Liability crystallises by charging provision at close of period per precedents (Wallace Brothers, Chatturam, Kalwa Devadattam, State of Kerala v. N. Sami Iyer).

holdings.text: The notice issued under s. 15 of the Act was legally valid and the appellants representing the original partners of the firm continued to be liable to be proceeded against under that section for the profits which had escaped taxation.

anchor.surface_text: It follows therefore that the numberice issued under s. 15 of the Act was legally valid and the appellants representing the original partners of the firm companytinued to be liable to be proceeded against under that section for the profits which had escaped taxation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combining repeal via adaptation, application of s.6 GCA to partial repeal, and accrual of liability at period-end preserves proceedings under s.15 post-repeal.

holdings.text: The liability to pay excess profits tax accrued immediately at the end of the chargeable accounting period and that liability was preserved under s. 6 of the General Clauses Act even though the Act stood repealed so far as Bellary district was concerned with effect from November 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the principle expressed in these authorities we are of the opinion that the liability to pay excess profits tax accrued immediately at the end of the chargeable accounting period and that liability was preserved under s. 6  c  of the General Clauses Act even though the Act stood repealed so far as Bellary district was companycerned with effect from November 1, 1956.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reaffirms accrual principle from authorities and preservation under s.6 despite repeal, directly answering appeal question.

precedents.citation: Wallace Brothers and Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of income-tax 1 16 I.T.R. 240, 244. P.C.

anchor.surface_text: In Wallace Brothers and Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of income-tax 1 , the Judicial Committee expounded in clear terms the scope of a tax liability under the Income-tax Act. It was observed by the Judicial Committee as follows the rate of tax for the year of assessment may be fixed after the close of the previous year and the assessment will necessarily be made after the close of that year. But the liability to tax arises by virtue of the charging section alone, and it arises number later than the close of the previous year, though quantification of the amount payable is postponed.

precedents.case_name: Wallace Brothers and Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: liability to tax arises by virtue of the charging section alone, and it arises not later than the close of the previous year, though quantification of the amount payable is postponed
precedents.cited_holding: the rate of tax for the year of assessment may be fixed after the close of the previous year and the assessment will necessarily be made after the close of that year. But the liability to tax arises by virtue of the charging section alone, and it arises number later than the close of the previous year, though quantification of the amount payable is postponed.

precedents.citation: Chatturam Horilram Ltd. v. C.I.T. 2 27 I.T.R. 769

anchor.surface_text: The same view has been expressed by this Court in Chatturam Horilram Ltd. v. C.I.T.  2  in which the legal position was reviewed  1  16 I.T.R. 240, 244.  P.C.   2  27 I.T.R. 769. with regard to the question of charge to income-tax.

precedents.cited_proposition: the legal position with regard to the question of charge to income-tax

precedents.citation: Kalwa Devadattam v. Union of India l 49 I.T.R. 165. A.I.R. 1966 S.C. 1415

anchor.surface_text: The same principle was reiterated by this Court in Kalwa Devadattam v. Union of India l . The question in that case was whether the liability of a Hindu undivided family arose before or after partition of the family. In that case, this Court speaking through Shah, J. stated in clear terms thus Under the Indian Income-tax Act liability to pay income-tax arises on the accrual of the income, and number from the companyputation made by the taxing authorities in the companyrse of assessment proceedings it arises at a point of time number later than the close of the year of account.

precedents.case_name: Kalwa Devadattam v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Under the Indian Income-tax Act liability to pay income-tax arises on the accrual of the income, and number from the companyputation made by the taxing authorities in the companyrse of assessment proceedings it arises at a point of time number later than the close of the year of account
precedents.cited_holding: Under the Indian Income-tax Act liability to pay income-tax arises on the accrual of the income, and number from the companyputation made by the taxing authorities in the companyrse of assessment proceedings it arises at a point of time number later than the close of the year of account.

precedents.citation: State of Kerala v. N. Sami lyer 2

anchor.surface_text: The same view has been taken in a recent case by this Court in State of Kerala v. N. Sami lyer  2   . In view of the principle expressed in these authorities we are of the opinion that the liability to pay excess profits tax accrued immediately at the end of the chargeable accounting period and that liability was preserved under s. 6  c  of the General Clauses Act even though the Act stood repealed so far as Bellary district was companycerned with effect from November 1, 1956.

precedents.case_name: State of Kerala v. N. Sami Iyer
precedents.cited_proposition: the same view on liability to pay income-tax arising on accrual of income not later than close of year of account
